name: 4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)aniline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3350

name: 4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)aniline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3350
Reason: The target compound is 4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)aniline, which is a complex aromatic molecule with multiple functional groups. To estimate the melting point, we consider the following functional groups and their effects: - Basic benzene unit: approximately 5°C as a reference starting point. The exact melting point point for benzene is 5.5°C, but we are using an approximate value for estimation. - Additional phenyl rings: Each additional phenyl ring increases the symmetry and surface area, raising the melting point. Assuming an increase of +20°C per phenyl ring, we have two extra rings, adding +40°C. - Benzotriazole moiety: This heterocyclic compound is known for its ability to raise melting points due to its rigid structure and potential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Estimating an increase of +60°C. - Aniline group: The presence of an amine can participate in hydrogen bonding, increasing the melting point. Estimating an increase of +20°C. - Overall increase due to molecular complexity and potential for intermolecular interactions: Approximately +10°C. Adding these effects together gives us an estimated melting point.
Prediction: The predicted melting point of 4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)aniline would be approximately 5 (basic benzene unit) + 40 (two additional phenyl rings) + 60 (benzotriazole moiety) + 20 (aniline group) + 10 (overall molecular complexity and intermolecular interactions) = 135°C.
